verse: After these things happened, two of the king of Egypt’s officers ·displeased [offended; sinned against] the king—·the man who served wine [cupbearer] to the king and the king’s baker [two important positions in the king’s court].
·The king [Pharaoh] became angry with his ·officer who served him wine and his [chief cupbearer and chief] baker,
so he put them in the prison of the chief butcher [37:36], the same ·prison [round house] where Joseph was ·kept [confined].
The chief butcher [37:36] put the two prisoners in Joseph’s care, and they stayed in prison for some time.
One night both the king’s ·officer who served him wine and the [cupbearer and] baker had a dream. Each had his own dream with its own meaning.
When Joseph came to them the next morning, he saw they were ·worried [troubled].
He asked ·the king’s [Pharaoh’s] officers who were with him, “Why ·do you look so unhappy [do you look so bad; are your faces bad/evil] today?”
The two men answered, “We both had dreams last night, but no one can explain their meaning to us.”
So the ·man who served wine to the king [chief cupbearer] told Joseph his dream. He said, “I dreamed I saw a vine, and
on the vine were three branches. I watched the branches bud and blossom, and then the [cluster of] grapes ripened.
I was holding ·the king’s [Pharaoh’s] cup, so I took the grapes and squeezed the juice into the cup. Then I gave ·it to [the cup into the palm of] ·the king [Pharaoh].”
Then Joseph said, “·I will explain the dream to you [This is its interpretation]. The three branches stand for three days.

Before the end of three days the king will ·free you [lift up your head], and he will allow you to return to your work. You will ·serve the king his wine just as you did before [give the cup into the hand of Pharaoh according to your former custom when you were his cupbearer].
But when ·you are free [it goes well for you], remember me. Be ·kind [loyal] to me, and ·tell the king about me [recall me to the king] so I can get out of this ·prison [house].
I was ·taken by force [stolen; snatched] from the land of the Hebrews, and I have done nothing here to deserve being put in ·prison [the pit; dungeon].”
The [chief] baker saw that ·Joseph’s explanation of the dream [the interpretation] was ·good [favorable], so he said to him, “I also had a dream. I dreamed there were three bread baskets on my head.
In the top basket were all kinds of baked food for ·the king [Pharaoh], but the birds were eating this food out of the basket on my head.”
Joseph answered, “·I will tell you what the dream means [This is its interpretation]. The three baskets stand for three days.
Before the end of three days, the king will ·cut off your head [lift up your head; v. 13]! He will hang your body on a ·pole [tree], and the birds will eat your flesh.”

Three days later, on his birthday, ·the king [Pharaoh] gave a ·feast [banquet] for all his ·officers [servants]. In front of his ·officers [servants], he ·released from prison the chief officer who served his wine and the chief baker [he lifted the head of the chief cupbearer and the head of the chief baker].
The king gave his chief ·officer who served wine [cupbearer] his old position, and once again he put the ·king’s cup of wine [cup] into ·the king’s [Pharaoh’s] hand.
But the king hanged the baker on a ·pole, just as Joseph had said he would [tree according to the interpretation of Joseph].
But the ·officer who served wine [chief cupbearer] did not remember Joseph. He forgot all about him.
